synthesis_conditions.comments: Uranyl–organic framework (MOF) with enhanced X-ray stopping power, high radiation, and hygroscopy hardness, and high light yield.

Stable after immersion into aqueous solution with pH ranging from 2 to 12. Maintains high crystallinity even with exposure under a high-energy radiation field with a received dose of up to 200 kGy (60Co gamma source).
Bright green emission observed when irradiated with X-rays, indicating SCU-9 is a self-activated scintillator based on intrinsic uranyl emission.
1.6 times higher than that of uranyl nitrate hexahydrate, suggesting dense structure significantly restricts non-radiative relaxation pathways.

synthesis_conditions.equipment: Spectrometer embedded within a laboratory X-ray source
synthesis_conditions.comments: Peak position and shape of the XEL spectrum is identical to that of the UV/Vis emission spectrum, implying identical emission mechanism.
XEL intensity of SCU-9 shows a remarkable increase with increased X-ray power. Shows a linear response as a function of intensity, a desirable property for scintillation applications.
SCU-9 has a notably shorter attenuation length in the energy region above 20 keV compared to CsI:Tl, implying higher X-ray attenuation efficiency.
SCU-9 maintains 65% of its luminescence intensity after exposure with 53 Gy X-ray radiation, showing higher radiation hardness compared to CsI:Tl and uranyl nitrate salt.
SCU-9 maintains 80% luminescence intensity after being subjected to 95% relative humidity for 30 minutes, showing decent hygroscopy hardness.
Inorganic uranyl borate compound. Even though the quantum yield of UV excited luminescence is close to 100%, its normalized XEL intensity is only one-third of that of SCU-9.
